{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3534599,"name":"Sanjan Sen","username":"yesiconcur","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/c68b51/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T19:25:13.971Z","cooked":"

Hi! Just recently, I figured out that Kraken x60 motor encoders remember their absolute position within a rotation when powered off and on. Is there a way to stop this in code or in the Tuner X application? I just want the Kraken x60 motor encoders to believe they are at 0 whenever they are powered on. Thanks

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T19:25:13.971Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":354,"reads":283,"readers_count":282,"score":1816.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Sanjan Sen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54009,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"100 Drive Coach and Software Alum"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/1","custom_user_title":"100 Drive Coach and Software Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3534608,"name":"Scott W","username":"Programming4907","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T19:32:42.122Z","cooked":"

According to the docs “The Talon FX and CANcoder sensors are always initialized to their absolute position in Phoenix 6.”

However, there is a setPosition method you can use:

talonFX.setPosition(0.0);
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T19:32:42.122Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":281,"readers_count":280,"score":76.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534610,"name":"Sanjan Sen","username":"yesiconcur","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/c68b51/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T19:34:27.683Z","cooked":"

Sure yeah but that means the position is reset upon deploy. I want to be able to set the zero position just once upon the robot powering up

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T19:34:27.683Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":262,"readers_count":261,"score":67.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Sanjan Sen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50699,"username":"Programming4907","name":"Scott W","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54009,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"100 Drive Coach and Software Alum"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/3","custom_user_title":"100 Drive Coach and Software Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534627,"name":"Scott W","username":"Programming4907","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T19:48:15.453Z","cooked":"

It sounds like your plan is to have the team set the mechanism to a certain starting position before starting a match, turn the robot on, and then have the motor itself function as the memory of that initial position.

It could work but it’s risky because if the motor ever lost power (due to a breaker popping, someone disconnecting a motor momentarily, etc.) then it would lose it’s position.

You really need a way to absolutely reference the mechanism. You can either add an external sensor and have it drive that direction until it sees it, or program it to drive (slowly with low torque) into a hard stop whenever it doesn’t know its position, then set position to zero when the torque peaks and the motion stops.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T19:48:15.453Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":225,"readers_count":224,"score":55.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54009,"username":"yesiconcur","name":"Sanjan Sen","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/c68b51/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534628,"name":"Sanjan Sen","username":"yesiconcur","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/c68b51/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T19:49:26.002Z","cooked":"

This method is the one that we want to use. We would like to avoid using an absolute encoder (because we currently have nowhere to put it) or have a homing sequence if possible.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T19:49:26.002Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":213,"readers_count":212,"score":67.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Sanjan Sen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50699,"username":"Programming4907","name":"Scott W","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54009,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"100 Drive Coach and Software Alum"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/6","custom_user_title":"100 Drive Coach and Software Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534636,"name":"Scott W","username":"Programming4907","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T19:56:38.065Z","cooked":"

I guess you could physically disconnect the load from the motor shaft, rotate the shaft until it reads zero absolute position, and then re-attach the shaft to the load. So you physically zero the motor to the mechanism.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T19:57:40.348Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":192,"readers_count":191,"score":58.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54009,"username":"yesiconcur","name":"Sanjan Sen","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/c68b51/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534644,"name":"Sanjan Sen","username":"yesiconcur","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/c68b51/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T20:02:45.432Z","cooked":"

That still wouldn’t solve the problem. You would turn on the mechanism move it more than a turn and the kraken would only remember where it is locally to that turn. you would never have a proper zero

If you call motor.setPosition(0) after creating the motor in code would it not set the position to zero on power up?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T20:24:15.165Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":161,"readers_count":160,"score":42.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Sanjan Sen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60754,"username":"Spaceman","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a5b964/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54009,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"100 Drive Coach and Software Alum"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/10","custom_user_title":"100 Drive Coach and Software Alum","reactions":[{"id":"question","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534692,"name":"Scott W","username":"Programming4907","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T20:40:21.095Z","cooked":"
yesiconcur:

You would turn on the mechanism move it more than a turn and the kraken would only remember where it is locally to that turn.

Only if it lost power, and you already said you’re ok with it losing position if it lost power inadvertently.

As long as you reset it with your checklist before you power up, it will power up at zero, and remember where it is even if you deploy. The deploy doesn’t reset the turn count.

yesiconcur:

you would never have a proper zero

For that you need a sensor.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T20:40:21.095Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":30.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534697,"name":"Hsifeulbhsifder","username":"Hsifeulbhsifder","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hsifeulbhsifder/{size}/7991_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T20:47:11.999Z","cooked":"

It is not on deploy, it is during the execution of your program. It will occur everytime it is called

when your defining your motor config, once its applied you can zero the motor using the talonFX.setPosition(0.0) like others have said. this runs on initialization, and will set the position once and not multiple times or on deploy as you suspect.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T20:51:13.727Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":47.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"meer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65870,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"the chief"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/13","custom_user_title":"the chief","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534704,"name":"Eugene Fang","username":"Eugene_Fang","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eugene_fang/{size}/65109_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T20:52:22.854Z","cooked":"
yesiconcur:

Is there a way to stop this in code or in the Tuner X application?

I don’t believe so.

[CTRE] 2024 Phoenix Software Now Available! Programming
Thanks for a great first season with the Krakens. 604 had a great experience with Phoenix 6 this year, except for one major request: Please bring back the option to boot to zero (which was available in Phoenix 5) instead of always booting to the absolute position of the motor. We’ve found that booting to the absolute position has a couple of issues: First, any time the motor gets un-clocked from the mechanism (e.g. during routine gearbox disassembly and maintenance), the absolute position of…
[CTRE] 2024 Phoenix Software Now Available! Programming
In most scenarios, if you want the motor to be zeroed at program startup, I would expect that calling m_talonFX.setPosition(0) after applying all configs (including invert) would be sufficient. Is there a scenario where you found that this did not work, or where you needed to use the RotorOffset config instead?
[CTRE] 2024 Phoenix Software Now Available! Programming
We intentionally want the motor to be zeroed on boot, rather than program startup. Zeroing on boot means we only have to check one time on power up that the robot is zeroed correctly, reducing risk of procedural errors. Zeroing on program startup means that any time the robot code is deployed or reset for any reason, the robot must be in the zero state. This is undesirable if a code reboot happens mid-match or during development where code is constantly getting deployed and forgetting to zero th…

W","username":"Programming4907","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T20:52:27.766Z","cooked":"

We’re down a bit of a rabbit hole here.

They don’t want to use any kind of external absolute encoder, or a home cam sensor to reference the position. They also don’t want to drive it into a hard stop to reference it.

They want to reference it with a checklist prior to powering on but then if they deploy code, they want it to remember its position after the deploy even if it’s not back at the pre-power-on checklist position.

And they’re OK with the fact that if the motor loses power during the match, that it’ll lose its position.

I suggested that the equivalent to the Phoenix 5 solution, where it boots to zero, is to mechanically clock the motor to absolute position zero when the mechanism is at zero.

(Frankly, the simplest solution is to flash the motor back to Phoenix 5 - I don’t know if that API is still FRC legal, or if it is, how much longer it will be.)

If you don’t want to physically disconnect the motor, just record the motor’s absolute position when the mechanism is at zero, save that in your config file or a constant, and then subtract that from your position reading, and it’ll work the same as booting to zero.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T20:58:44.643Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":36.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534716,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T21:09:13.073Z","cooked":"
yesiconcur:

We would like to avoid using an absolute encoder (because we currently have nowhere to put it) or have a homing sequence if possible.

Both cannot be true, unless you’re fine with having the mechanism rendered useless in the middle of a playoff match because of something like a breaker trip or loose power wire. There is always a risk in a match that your motor temporarily loses power and reboots, in which case you need a way to determine, or at least reset, the position of the system.

With that said, there are some things you can do to keep things simple in the base case. If you know that your robot should just about always be in the zero position at program startup, then you can use setPosition(0) to reset the position. If that’s not necessarily the case, but you know the position should just about always be zero when the robot is powered on, then you can set the FeedbackRotorOffset config.

However, regardless of what you do at robot or program startup, you will need a homing procedure to handle the worst case scenario, because it will always seem to happen at the worst possible timing. And your homing procedure will want to use something like setPosition(0).

Programming4907:

Frankly, the simplest solution is to flash the motor back to Phoenix 5 - I don’t know if that API is still FRC legal, or if it is, how much longer it will be.

The Talon FX and Pigeon 2 are no longer supported in Phoenix 5 this season.

I don’t really want to add another offset. I just wanted to know if there was some config to bring back booting to zero instead of to an absolute position

bhall-ctre:

Both cannot be true, unless you’re fine with having the mechanism rendered useless in the middle of a playoff match because of something like a breaker trip or loose power wire.

You can have a homing sequence but not want to run it at the start of auto in order to save time, but still want to rely on boot-to-zero behavior instead of an absolute encoder for the reasons stated above.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T04:03:19.570Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":69.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492470,"topic_slug":"how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on","display_username":"Eugene Fang","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":"The-Blue-Alliance","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/0/2/02b18ea7720fea44e77469bb5261acf1c7045a6e.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":67,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7439,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-reset-kraken-motor-internal-encoder-upon-power-on/492470/19","custom_user_title":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535114,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T04:18:04.246Z","cooked":"

The boot to zero behavior can be handled by either of the methods previously mentioned:

bhall-ctre:

With that said, there are some things you can do to keep things simple in the base case. If you know that your robot should just about always be in the zero position at program startup, then you can use setPosition(0) to reset the position. If that’s not necessarily the case, but you know the position should just about always be zero when the robot is powered on, then you can set the FeedbackRotorOffset config.

In practice, there shouldn’t be a difference between robot startup and robot program startup (outside of anything you do at your workshop), which is why we typically recommend doing setPosition(0).

Sure, this just means any mechanism you have needs to be in its zero position upon every deploy. You can see how this gets tedious and dangerous, if you accidentally redeploy but dont reset all of your mechanisms to their exact zero. The boot to zero upon start up/power up alleviates this issue. Instead of zeroing upon every deploy, you only have to make sure your mechanism is zeroed once upon power up. I believe this is how it worked previously, I just don’t know why it needed to be changed. It would be nice to still have that option
